author: Donna-Lee Biddle
title: Kuggeleijn rape trial: Jury retires
text:
Kuggeleijn rape trial: Jury retires DONNA-LEE BIDDLE Last updated 10:08, February 24 2017 DOMINICO ZAPATA/FAIRFAX NZ. 
Northern Districts cricketer Scott Christopher Kuggeleijn arrived at the Hamilton District Court on Monday, for the first day of a week-long trial. 
The jury in a rape trial of a cricket star is set to decide whether the sex he had with a woman in her bed was consensual. 
Northern Districts all-rounder Scott Christopher Kuggeleijn, 25, faces a single charge of raping a woman in May 2015. 
The jury, at the Hamilton District Court, retired on Friday morning to consider their verdict. 
The prosecution says Kuggeleijn was persistent and didn't take no for an answer, but the defence says the complainant eventually relented as she did not want to come across as a "b.... or a tease". 
Judge David Wilson, QC, also gave his closing statement to the jury on Friday. 
"Consent means true consent given by a person that can make a rational decision," Wilson said. 
"Consent given reluctantly or later regretted, is still consent. 
"In order to convict Mr Kuggeleijn you will have to accept the [Crown's] evidence without a reasonable doubt." 
Wilson urged the jury of six women and six men to consider all of the evidence. 
It is irrelevant that the defendant was a sports star or that the complainant was an educated young woman, Wilson said. 
"You don't have to accept everything the witness says, you can accept one part and you can have some doubts. It's important you only consider the evidence you've heard during this trial. 
"You're the sole judges of fact." 
The jury have heard from ten witnesses over the last week, including evidence from the complainant and the defendant. 
On Thursday, lawyers for the Crown and the defence gave their closing statements. 
In her closing statement, Crown prosecutor Jacinda Foster told the jury the case was not complicated and that the account given by the complainant was at the heart of the Crown's case 
"[Her] intoxication should have no bearing on her credibility or her reliability," Foster said. 
"[The defendant was never entitled to assume that one act of physical intimacy would ultimately lead to an act of sexual intercourse." 
Defence counsel Phillip Morgan, QC, said the complainant relented because after two initial refusals to have sex and partaking in foreplay, she could not turn him down. 
"She couldn't turn this man down yet again because she would then be thought of as a b.... or a tease," Morgan said. 
My client respected the complainant's wishes at night "when he could've had her so easily when she was drunk", Morgan said. 
"That's not the behaviour of a rapist, is it?" Morgan said. 
"This case demonstrates clearly that she had consented. My client didn't intend to hurt somebody but he did." 
The jury have retired to decide a verdict. - Stuff
